lessons.title: Internet and IP Addresses
masteryOutcomes: Define the internet as a network of connected computers
Define what an IP address is
Understand why computers need IP addresses to communicate

lessons.title: Clients and Servers
masteryOutcomes: Define client and server
Understand how clients and servers interact
Identify clients and servers in common real-world examples

lessons.title: Browser: the Web Client
masteryOutcomes: Identify the browser as a client
Explain what a browser does when loading a web page
Connect HTML and CSS to what the browser renders

lessons.title: Frontend vs Backend
masteryOutcomes: Distinguish frontend and backend
Connect frontend to browsers and UI code
Connect backend to servers and data logic, including databases

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Internet and IP address basics
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Strengthen your understanding of what the internet is and why IP addresses are required for computers to communicate.

lessons.title: DNS in Practice
masteryOutcomes: Describe how a domain is resolved to an IP address
Use nslookup or an online tool to find an IP
Trace DNS as part of a real web request

lessons.title: HTTP: the Web Protocol
masteryOutcomes: Define HTTP as a communication protocol
Understand why APIs commonly use HTTP
Connect HTTP to the request-response model

lessons.title: Responses and Status Codes
masteryOutcomes: Identify the main parts of an HTTP response
Define status codes
Interpret success and error responses (2xx, 4xx, 5xx)

lessons.title: Inspecting HTTP Traffic
masteryOutcomes: Open browser Inspect / DevTools
Locate the Network tab
Identify requests and responses made by a web page

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: DNS lookup exploration
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply your knowledge of DNS by using nslookup or an online tool to trace how a domain name maps to an IP address. Output: A short report listing several domains, their resolved IP addresses, and notes on what you observed.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Task Tracker POST Requests
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Construct and send POST requests with JSON payloads in Postman to create new resources according to API docs. Output: One or more successful POST requests in Postman that create ‚Äútasks‚Äù (or similar items) and show the created resource in the response.

lessons.title: Python as an HTTP Client
masteryOutcomes: Explain how Python can act as a client
Connect Python programs to the client-server model
Identify Python‚Äôs role compared to browser and Postman

lessons.title: The `requests` Library
masteryOutcomes: Import and use the requests library with a common, public API
Send a basic GET request in Python
Inspect the response object

lessons.title: Responses in Python
masteryOutcomes: Access the status code from a response
Access the response body
Connect Python responses to HTTP responses from Unit 2
